title: The Two Doctors
dialogue_triumphs: 'Eternal blackness. No more sunsets. No more gumblejacks. Never more a butterfly.'
goofs: The Androgums speak English (as Dona Arana recognizes).
Despite being a recluse, she is able to supply Shockeye with a current list of Seville restaurants.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord protagonist, currently in his sixth incarnation
continuity_notes.current_status: Becomes a vegetarian after this adventure

continuity_notes.name: Sontarans
continuity_notes.description: Militaristic clone race, taller than humans in this story
continuity_notes.current_status: Group Marshal Stike leads the 9th Sontaran Battle Group

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: Time and space travel machine used by the Doctor
continuity_notes.current_status: Requires symbiotic control from a Time Lord

continuity_notes.name: Kartz-Reimer Module
continuity_notes.current_status: Turned into a functioning time machine by the Doctor

technobabble: Ripples in time can be measured on the Bocca Scale
The Doctor talks of the holistic fabric of time
Time Lords have symbiotic nuclei affording protection from molecular break-up
roots: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
links: Peri offers the Doctor celery when he seemingly faints
The Doctor talks of jelly babies and his recorder

locations.name: Space station Chimera
locations.description: Space station created by various Third Zone governments
locations.current_status: Location of the story's opening events

locations.name: Seville
locations.current_status: Primary Earth location for the story

untold_adventures: The Doctor has been to Seville before
The Doctor attended the inauguration of space station Chimera
additional_notes: This is the only Doctor Who story to mention Shepton Mallet.
bottom_line: An anti-meat message via the Doctor Who equivalent of a Peter Greenaway film. The tone is wrong, most notably in the meaningless murder of Oscar. The location filming is excellent, and below the tasteless surface it's actually a passable runaround. But Troughton deserved a better closing bow, which just goes to show that even Robert Holmes slipped up every now and again.
